awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Reverse Data Management: Reverse-Engineering Data Transformations to Understand, Diagnose, and Manipulate Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Today, data is critical in almost every aspect of society, including healthcare, education, economy, and science. Applications in these domains have benefited from the rapid growth and increased availability of data through online repositories, marketplaces, and other sharing platforms. However, because data is easily shared and reused, it has become less curated and less reliable. Data is often misused because its validity and origin are unclear, and mistakes easily propagate as data is often used to derive other data. This project will design and develop new technologies to assist data-reliant applications in overcoming these challenges, by extending data management capabilities to support operations that reverse-engineer data transformations. Understanding and reasoning with data derivations will lead to better understanding of surprising observations, more accurate and efficient diagnoses of problems, and better tools for making data-driven decisions and planning. This work will broadly impact society through the development of new data analysis capabilities, which will, in turn, improve data quality and positively affect data-driven processes. Overall, these improvements will increase the positive impact that data and computing systems have on society.

This project will establish the theoretical foundations and will address practical challenges to support reverse data management capabilities in database systems. Reverse data management focuses on reverse transformations that manipulate input data on behalf of desired outcomes in the output data (as opposed to traditional data management that typically focuses on forward-moving data flows, such as querying, aggregation, and indexing). The research goal of this project is to augment database systems with user-facing reverse data management functionality. This project will target three reverse data management needs of modern applications: (1) assisting users with understanding data and verifying data-based computation results, (2) diagnosing problems by tracing the root causes of data errors, and (3) identifying changes in data and processes that lead to improved, more desirable results.

For further information see the project web site at: http://rdm.cs.umass.edu
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Database systems are particularly efficient at handling forward-moving data flows, where source data is subjected to transformations and evolves through queries, aggregations, and view definitions to form a new target data instance. This forward paradigm underpins most data management tasks today, such as querying, data integration, data mining, clustering, and indexing. However, a lot of important problems, such as data cleaning, data generation, and others, rely on reverse transformations: determining the changes to the input that would achieve a desired change in an output. Such reverse transformations are conceptually more complex to define and computationally harder to achieve.  This project augmented traditional database technologies with user-facing reverse data management functionality, allowing users to effectively express and efficiently solve important problems in this domain, such as deriving explanations for query results, and diagnosing data errors.

Intellectual Merit:

This project developed models, algorithms, and database support for reverse data management tasks along three key directions: 

(1) Data understanding: When analyzing complex data sets, users are often interested in the reasons for surprising observations. An unexpected query result may be an indication of error, or a manifestation of an interesting phenomenon or fact.  This project produced tools to support explanations in data-driven systems.

(2) Error diagnosis: Poor data quality imposes huge risks on businesses and has been recently estimated to cost the US economy $3 trillion per year.  However, errors do not happen in a vacuum and are often manifestations of systemic issues with the underlying data or system.  This project developed tools to diagnose such errors in relational and non-relational systems.

(3) Complex reasoning: Several reverse data management problems can be expressed as a set of complex requirements over an output (e.g., constraints that data should satisfy, a model of user preferences, etc.). This project contributed to scalable solutions in modeling and evaluating such complex requirements in a variety of settings, including constraint optimization over relational data and subjective document summarization.

Broader Impacts:

Data is an integral part of all scientific disciplines, and also drives many modern systems. This project produced tools that assist scientists and occasional users alike in gaining a better understanding of their data, diagnosing errors, and implementing repairs and other desirable changes.  These tools enhance the usability of data systems and promote users' trust in their operation.  In addition, the project created educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and supported the training of several junior scientists.


Last Modified: 02/03/2022
Modified by: Alexandra Meliou
